"You‚Äôve probably heard this a million times already, but just the people. The community environment that exists here is truly unique in a way that‚Äôs almost indescribable. https://t.co/qK88JeK0N0

"I was on the swim and dive team, so pretty much all of us came back. We just really wanted to be able to see each other. For the friends!"

-Allison Fitzgerald, of Grand Rapids, Michigan, who works as a nurse tech at a children‚Äôs hospital, a diving coach, and a nanny https://t.co/aSXHLTIAfo

"It was a big deal to my family. At the same time, graduating college is a big achievement. I think it‚Äôs important to come back here and celebrate what we did, because we worked our butts off."

"I wanted to get the feeling of walking across the stage and properly obtaining a diploma ‚Äî even though I already have it."

‚ÄúI wanted to see some old faces, meet friends and professors ‚Äî walk down memory lane, you know?‚Äù

"We all did it so far removed and so separately. As special as Denison made that graduation ‚Äî and they went out of their way to make the pandemic as normal as possible for us  ‚Äî nothing beats this.

"Most importantly, it‚Äôs a moment of closure. At the end of the day (in 2020), most of us were somewhere where we couldn‚Äôt celebrate much. I walked to a park, and moved my tassel, and that was kind of it. https://t.co/H8Zn424fjX
Here's what brought them back two years later. https://t.co/2bVN6G1y7v

In many ways, the class moved on. They scattered across the world, launching promising careers or diving deeper into their studies.

They're adults now, poised, confident, free of the wobbly uncertainty of fresh graduates.

But for many, something's been missing.

For Denison's Class of 2020, the global pandemic meant a swift halt to in-person classes just months shy of graduation.

It also meant a virtual Commencement. Individual ceremonies held in living rooms. No applause, no cap toss.

This walk was two years in the making. 

On the morning of June 12, 2022, over half of Denison's Class of 2020 returned for their Commencement ceremony. 

They paused their lives to get here. Traveled here by car, by plane. Some crossed oceans. 

It meant that much. 

But why? üßµ https://t.co/pFa0mP0GEA
